Shannon Fagan - Getty Images Even in 2024, there’s  no shortage of obstacles  keeping women from leadership positions
The problem of short female CEO tenures doesn’t appear to have notably worsened since the pandemic, Wiggins says
Rather, the greater number of women in leadership at any given time is just making the problem starker
“We know that the first two years are critical to success,” he goes on
That means a CEO who, in another macroeconomic landscape, might have had some wiggle room to establish themselves or roll out their plans, these days is forced to cobble together a team quickly
Russell Reynolds, for its part, encourages a bit more leniency on the part of boards; no one wins when a string of CEOs depart before they have a chance to make things better
That’s alongside the fact that advancements are slowly, steadily coming
For the first time last year,  over 10%  of CEOs of Fortune 500 companies were women
“Diverse leaders have had to continuously reinvent and adapt at a personal level throughout their careers,”  Accenture  CEO Julie Sweet  told  Fortune’s   Emma Hinchliffe

”   Plus, with adequate attention to fostering and uplifting female talent, the Fortune 500 could stand to double its percentage of women leaders within five years, Jane Stevenson, global leader for the succession practice at consultancy  Korn Ferry , told Hinchliffe
